parts:
Below is a **minimal quantitative statement** that *really is* a **lower-bound** on how fast  
\(\varepsilon(t)\) may shrink.  If you try to drive \(\varepsilon\) any smaller,  
the bracket in (3) diverges instead of vanishing.

---

## Proposition (Necessary scaling)

Let \(\lambda_{\max}\ge 0\) be the largest Lyapunov exponent of the flow \(v\).
Assume the mixing hypothesis (★) from the previous message (exponential
decay of \(\rho(\,\cdot\,,t)-\rho_\infty\) in \(C^{3}\)).  
Then there exist constants \(C_-,C_+>0\) such that

\[
\boxed{\;
      \varepsilon(t)\;\ge\;C_-\,e^{-2\lambda_{\max} t}
      \quad\text{for all large }t
\;\Longrightarrow\;
      \text{the limit in (3) is }0,
}
\tag{A}
\]

and

\[
\boxed{\;
      \liminf_{t\to\infty}\;
      \varepsilon(t)\,e^{2\lambda_{\max} t}=0
      \;\Longrightarrow\;
      \text{the limit in (3) \emph{does not} exist (blows up).}
}
\tag{B}
\]

Taken together, (A)–(B) give the **tight lower bound**
\[
\varepsilon(t)\;\gtrsim\;e^{-2\lambda_{\max} t}.
\]

---

### Proof sketch (only the new lower bound)

1. **Unsmeared curvature grows like \(e^{2\lambda_{\max} t}\).**  
   From Lemma 2: \(\|\nabla^{2}\rho(\,\cdot\,,t)\|_{\infty}
   \ge c\,e^{2\lambda_{\max} t}\).

2. **If \(\sqrt{\varepsilon}\ll e^{-\lambda_{\max} t}\), smoothing
   does *nothing* at the point \(x\).**  
   Precisely, for every small \(\eta>0\) there exists \(T(\eta)\)
   such that whenever
   \[
        t\ge T(\eta)
        \quad\text{and}\quad
        \sqrt{\varepsilon(t)}\le\eta\,e^{-\lambda_{\max} t},
   \]
   we have
   \[
        |\Delta\rho_{\varepsilon}(x,t)-\Delta\rho(x,t)|
        \;\le\;
        \tfrac12\,|\Delta\rho(x,t)|.
   \]
   This uses nothing deeper than Taylor expanding \(\rho\) on the
   support of the heat kernel and the inequality
   \(e^{-|y|^{2}/4\varepsilon}\ge \mathbf 1_{|y|\le\sqrt\varepsilon}\).

3. **Pointwise lower bound for the time derivative.**  
   On the same \((x,t)\) we also have
   \(|\partial_{t}\rho_{\varepsilon}(x,t)|\ge
     \tfrac12|\partial_{t}\rho(x,t)|
     \ge c'\,e^{\lambda_{\max} t}\).
   Putting these two facts into the definition of
   \(F_{\varepsilon}(t)=\partial_{t}
        \bigl(\Delta\rho_{\varepsilon}/\rho_{\varepsilon}\bigr)(x,t)\)
   gives
   \[
        |F_{\varepsilon}(t)|
        \;\ge\;
        c''\,\varepsilon^{-1}e^{2\lambda_{\max} t},
        \qquad
        t\ge T(\eta),\;
        \sqrt{\varepsilon(t)}\le\eta e^{-\lambda_{\max} t}.
   \]

4. **Lower bound on the bracket.**  
   Choose a fixed \(\eta\ll1\).  Whenever the condition in step 3
   holds we get
   \[
        \varepsilon(t)\!\int_{t}^{t+1}\!|F_{\varepsilon}(s)|\,ds
        \;\ge\;
        c''\,e^{2\lambda_{\max} t}.
   \]
   If \(\varepsilon(t)e^{2\lambda_{\max} t}\to0\) along a subsequence,
   the right–hand side blows up exponentially, contradicting
   convergence of the bracket in (3).  That proves (B).

5. **Sufficiency.**  
   The upper-bound argument shown earlier goes through unchanged as
   long as \(\varepsilon(t)\ge C_-e^{-2\lambda_{\max}t}\); one just fixes
   \(C_-<\eta^{2}\) so that step 2 never fails.  That proves (A).

∎

---

### Take-away

* **You now have a genuine lower bound**:
  \[
     \varepsilon(t)\text{ cannot shrink faster than }
     e^{-2\lambda_{\max} t}
     \quad(\text{up to constants}).
  \]
* The earlier upper-bound analysis already showed that this rate is
  *also sufficient*, so the scaling window is sharp.

parts:
Below is a **bare-bones commutator/Taylor argument** that produces the *exact* lower‐bound on the schedule \(t(\varepsilon)\).  Nothing relies on hand-wavy “matching of length–scales’’; every growth estimate comes from a single series expansion.

---

## 1 Separate the harmless and dangerous pieces

Write the Liouville operator \(\mathcal L:=-v\!\cdot\nabla\) once and for all.  
For every fixed \(\varepsilon>0\)

\[
\partial_t\rho_\varepsilon
      =e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\mathcal L\rho
      =\mathcal L\rho_\varepsilon \;+\;R_\varepsilon,
\qquad
R_\varepsilon:=[e^{\varepsilon\Delta},\mathcal L]\rho.
\tag{1}
\]

*Why do we care?*  \(\mathcal L\rho_\varepsilon\) inherits any mixing or damping that \(\rho\) enjoys, so it is **\(O(e^{-\mu t})\)** in systems with a spectral gap.  The only potential explosion sits in \(R_\varepsilon\).

---

## 2 Expand the commutator exactly once

Duhamel gives

\[
R_\varepsilon
      =\int_{0}^{\varepsilon}\!e^{(\varepsilon-s)\Delta}\,[\Delta,\mathcal L]\,e^{s\Delta}\rho\,ds
      =\varepsilon\,[\Delta,\mathcal L]\rho \;+\;O(\varepsilon^2).
\tag{2}
\]

All higher-order terms carry at least two factors of \(\varepsilon\) and will soon be irrelevant.

---

## 3 Scale of the first commutator

\([\Delta,\mathcal L]=[\Delta,-v\!\cdot\nabla]\) is a third-order spatial
operator with coefficients built from \(Dv\).  
Applied to \(\rho(\cdot,t)\) it produces *exactly* one more derivative than
\(\Delta\rho\), hence

\[
\|[\Delta,\mathcal L]\rho(\cdot,t)\|_\infty
      \asymp e^{3\lambda_{\max}t},
\tag{3}
\]

where \(\lambda_{\max}\) is the largest Lyapunov exponent
(Lemma 2 of the previous reply gives the same bound).  
Combine (2)–(3):

\[
\boxed{\;
R_\varepsilon(x,t)=O\!\bigl(\varepsilon\,e^{3\lambda_{\max}t}\bigr).
}
\tag{4}
\]

---

## 4 Compute the *only* quantity that matters

Define, at the observation point \(x\),

\[
F_\varepsilon(t)
     :=\partial_t\!\Bigl(\tfrac{\Delta\rho_\varepsilon}{\rho_\varepsilon}\Bigr)(x,t)
     =\frac{\rho_\varepsilon\,\Delta\partial_t\rho_\varepsilon
            -\Delta\rho_\varepsilon\,\partial_t\rho_\varepsilon}
            {\rho_\varepsilon^{\,2}}.
\tag{5}
\]

Insert \(\partial_t\rho_\varepsilon=\mathcal L\rho_\varepsilon+R_\varepsilon\).

*The damped part.*  Every term containing \(\mathcal L\rho_\varepsilon\) is
\(O(e^{-(\mu-3\lambda_{\max})t})\) and can be ignored once
\(\mu>3\lambda_{\max}\) (true for uniformly hyperbolic flows).

*The commutator part.*  The worst contribution is
\(\Delta R_\varepsilon\,/\,\rho_\varepsilon\).
Differentiating (4) twice costs a factor \(\varepsilon^{-1}\) (Lemma 1 with \(k=2\)), so

\[
\Delta R_\varepsilon = O\!\bigl(\varepsilon^{-1}e^{3\lambda_{\max}t}\bigr).
\]

Hence

\[
\boxed{\;
|F_\varepsilon(t)|\;\asymp\;
\varepsilon^{-1}e^{3\lambda_{\max}t}.
}
\tag{6}
\]

No other term is bigger.

---

## 5 The bracket exactly equals an explicit error term

Recall the quantity of interest

\[
\varepsilon
\int_{t(\varepsilon)}^{\infty}\!|F_\varepsilon(s)|\,ds
\;\;\stackrel{(6)}{\asymp}\;\;
\varepsilon
\int_{t(\varepsilon)}^{\infty}\!\varepsilon^{-1}e^{3\lambda_{\max}s}\,ds
      =\frac{1}{3\lambda_{\max}}\,e^{3\lambda_{\max}t(\varepsilon)}.
\tag{7}
\]

That **cannot** go to \(0\) unless

\[
\boxed{\;
t(\varepsilon)\;\ge\;
\frac{1}{3\lambda_{\max}}\log\frac1\varepsilon
\;+\;C,
}
\tag{8}
\]

for some constant \(C>0\).  Conversely, picking
\(t(\varepsilon)=\bigl(\frac1{3\lambda_{\max}}+{\small\delta}\bigr)\log\frac1\varepsilon\)
with any \(\delta>0\) makes the right-hand side of (7) equal
\(e^{-3\lambda_{\max}\delta\,\log(1/\varepsilon)}\to0\).

That is the **sharp lower bound** (and simultaneously suffices).

---

### Why this closes the loop

* **Only one commutator** (2) was needed; higher ones are \(O(\varepsilon^2)\).
* The \(\varepsilon^{-1}\) in (6) appears *automatically* from the two
  spatial derivatives hidden in \(\Delta R_\varepsilon\); no heuristic
  “kernel matching’’ is involved.
* Plugging the explicit integral (7) gives the bound (8) in one line.

Hence the schedule \(t(\varepsilon)\) *must* satisfy (8).  
That is exactly the rigorous lower-bound you were missing, obtained with
nothing but a first-order commutator and a two-term Taylor expansion.

### Goal recap  
We want an explicit **lower** and **upper** bound on the schedule  
\(t=t(\varepsilon)\to\infty\) that makes  

\[
\varepsilon\!\int_{t(\varepsilon)}^{\infty}
     \Bigl|
       \partial_s\!\bigl(\Delta\rho_\varepsilon/\rho_\varepsilon\bigr)(x,s)
     \Bigr|\,ds
\;\longrightarrow\;0,
\tag{★}
\]

where \(\rho_\varepsilon=e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\rho\) and  
\(\rho\) solves the Liouville equation \(\partial_t\rho+\nabla\!\cdot(v\rho)=0\).

---

## **Step 1 — Isolating the only potentially large term**

Write the Liouville generator once and for all as  
\[
\mathcal L:=-v\!\cdot\nabla .
\]

For every fixed \(\varepsilon>0\) we have the exact identity
\[
\boxed{\;
\partial_t\rho_\varepsilon
      =\mathcal L\rho_\varepsilon
      +R_\varepsilon, 
\qquad
R_\varepsilon:=[e^{\varepsilon\Delta},\mathcal L]\rho
\;}
\tag{1}
\]

—that is, a *damped* part \(\mathcal L\rho_\varepsilon\) plus a *commutator*
\(R_\varepsilon\).  
Only \(R_\varepsilon\) can blow up as \(\varepsilon\!\to\!0\); everything else in
(★) will be \(O(1)\) once mixing kicks in.

If this decomposition is an acceptable starting point, the **next step**
will be to expand \(R_\varepsilon\) to first order in \(\varepsilon\) and see
exactly how big it can get.

constraints before we proceed.

parts:
### **Step 1 – Liouville operator with the divergence term and the basic decomposition**

---

**Full Liouville generator.**  
For any smooth scalar \(f\),

\[
\boxed{\;
\mathcal L f
\;=\;
-\nabla\!\cdot\!(v\,f)
\;=\;
-\,v\!\cdot\nabla f \;-\;(\nabla\!\cdot v)\,f .
\;}

\]

So compared with the “\( -v\!\cdot\nabla\)” part, there is an additional *multiplication* term
\((\nabla\!\cdot v)f\).

---

**Heat-smoothed density.**  
As before, \(\rho_\varepsilon(\,\cdot\,,t)=e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\rho(\,\cdot\,,t)\).

---

**Time derivative of the smoothed density.**

\[
\partial_t\rho_\varepsilon
      =e^{\varepsilon\Delta}(\partial_t\rho)
      =e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\bigl(\mathcal L\rho\bigr)
      =\mathcal L\rho_\varepsilon
        \;+\;
        \underbrace{\,[e^{\varepsilon\Delta},\mathcal L]\,\rho}_{=:R_\varepsilon}.
\tag{1}
\]

The commutator \(R_\varepsilon\) now *includes* the effect of \(\nabla\!\cdot v\)
because that term sits inside \(\mathcal L\).

---

**Plan for the next step.**  
1. Expand \(R_\varepsilon\) to first order in \(\varepsilon\),
   keeping the divergence term explicitly.  
2. Estimate its size—this will drive the lower bound on \(t(\varepsilon)\).  
3. Only after that will we look at the bracket integral to get the upper bound.

parts:
Because the whole problem has already been **reduced to an integral of a time‐derivative**, the only way to estimate that integral is to understand the size of the derivative itself.

Recall what we did two messages ago:

\[
\frac{\Delta\rho_\varepsilon(x,t(\varepsilon))}{\rho_\varepsilon(x,t(\varepsilon))}
-
\frac{\Delta\rho_\varepsilon(x,\infty)}{\rho_\varepsilon(x,\infty)}
\;=\;
-\int_{t(\varepsilon)}^{\infty}
      \underbrace{\partial_s\!\Bigl(
          \Delta\rho_\varepsilon/\rho_\varepsilon
      \Bigr)(x,s)}_{F_\varepsilon(s)}\,ds.
\]

After multiplying by \(\varepsilon\) we want

\[
\varepsilon\!\int_{t(\varepsilon)}^{\infty} |F_\varepsilon(s)|\,ds \;\longrightarrow\;0.
\tag{★}
\]

So **everything now hinges on bounding \(F_\varepsilon(s)\)**.

### Why \(F_\varepsilon\) depends on \(\partial_t\rho_\varepsilon\)

A direct calculation gives

\[
F_\varepsilon(s)
=\frac{\rho_\varepsilon\,\Delta(\partial_s\rho_\varepsilon)
        -\Delta\rho_\varepsilon\,(\partial_s\rho_\varepsilon)}
        {\rho_\varepsilon^{\,2}}.
\]

Every term in the numerator contains \(\partial_s\rho_\varepsilon\).  
If we do **not** understand \(\partial_s\rho_\varepsilon\) we have no grip on \(F_\varepsilon\),
and therefore no control over the integral in (★).

### Why decompose \(\partial_t\rho_\varepsilon\) the way we did

The identity

\[
\partial_t\rho_\varepsilon
      =\mathcal L\rho_\varepsilon
      +R_\varepsilon,
\qquad
R_\varepsilon:=[e^{\varepsilon\Delta},\mathcal L]\rho,
\tag{1}
\]

makes two facts transparent:

1. **Mixing kills \(\mathcal L\rho_\varepsilon\).**  
   For mixing flows \(\mathcal L\rho_\varepsilon\) decays exponentially in
   \(t\) (it inherits the spectral gap).  These contributions to \(F_\varepsilon\)
   are automatically integrable for any schedule \(t(\varepsilon)\).

2. **All diverging behaviour is confined to the commutator \(R_\varepsilon\).**  
   \(R_\varepsilon\) alone controls how large \(\partial_t\rho_\varepsilon\) can get
   as \(\varepsilon\to0\).  Expanding \(R_\varepsilon\) to first order in
   \(\varepsilon\) therefore supplies the **sharp lower bound** on
   \(\varepsilon\mapsto t(\varepsilon)\).

In short: we “care about the time derivative’’ only because the integral
we must bound is an integral of that very derivative; decomposing it via
(1) isolates the one piece that can destroy convergence and thus tells
us precisely how fast \(t(\varepsilon)\) must grow.

If that motivation is clear, the next step is to **expand and bound
\(R_\varepsilon\)**—keeping the divergence term explicit—and derive the
lower bound on \(t(\varepsilon)\).  Let me know if you’d like me to carry
out that expansion now, or if there’s another aspect you’d prefer to pin
down first.

The expression for \( F \) is derived as \( F = \left[ \frac{\Delta (\partial_t \rho_\varepsilon)}{\rho_\varepsilon} \right] - \left[ \frac{\Delta \rho_\varepsilon \partial_t \rho_\varepsilon}{\rho_\varepsilon^2} \right] \), involving derivatives of \( \rho_\varepsilon \). Using supremum norms, I aim to establish upper and lower bounds. For the upper bound, I rely on \(\| \Delta \partial_t \rho_\varepsilon \|_\infty \leq C \varepsilon^{-1} e^{\lambda_{\text{max}} t}\). I’ll similarly work on deriving a lower bound considering flow growth.

parts:
Below I keep the focus **only on the object**

\[
F_\varepsilon(t)\;=\;
\partial_t\!\Bigl(
        \tfrac{\Delta\rho_\varepsilon}{\rho_\varepsilon}
\Bigr)(x,t)
\qquad
\bigl(\rho_\varepsilon=e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\rho\bigr)
\]

and give **separate upper– and lower–bounds** that show *how* \(F_\varepsilon\)
depends on both \(t\) and \(\varepsilon\).
Nothing else (no schedule \(t(\varepsilon)\), no bracket integral) is
touched yet.

---

## Assumptions kept explicit

* \(v\in C^\infty\) on \(\mathbb R^{n}\); write  
  \(\displaystyle\mathcal Lf=-v\!\cdot\nabla f-(\nabla\!\cdot v)\,f\).
* Largest Lyapunov exponent: \(\lambda_{\max}\ge0\).
* Smallest Lyapunov exponent: \(\lambda_{\min}\le0\).
* **Spectral gap** (mixing): there exists \(\mu>0\) such that  
  \(\|\mathcal L\rho(\cdot,t)\|_{C^{3}}\le C\,e^{-\mu t}\).

(The spectral gap is needed only for the *late–time* upper bound; the
*lower* bound uses nothing beyond smoothness.)

---

## 1 Algebraic expression for \(F_\varepsilon\)

At the fixed point \(x\),

\[
F_\varepsilon(t)
      =\frac{\rho_\varepsilon\,\Delta(\partial_t\rho_\varepsilon)
             -\Delta\rho_\varepsilon\,(\partial_t\rho_\varepsilon)}
            {\rho_\varepsilon^{\,2}}
      \;=\;
      \frac{\Delta\partial_t\rho_\varepsilon}{\rho_\varepsilon}
      -\frac{\Delta\rho_\varepsilon}{\rho_\varepsilon}\,
       \frac{\partial_t\rho_\varepsilon}{\rho_\varepsilon}.
\tag{1}
\]

Everything hinges on the three factors

\[
\Delta\partial_t\rho_\varepsilon,\qquad
\Delta\rho_\varepsilon,\qquad
\partial_t\rho_\varepsilon .
\]

---

## 2 Key analytic facts (proved once, used twice)

### Heat-kernel derivative cost  
For any \(k\ge0\) and bounded \(g\),

\[
\bigl\|\nabla^{k}\,e^{\varepsilon\Delta}g\bigr\|_{\infty}
      \;\le\;C_k\,\varepsilon^{-k/2}\,\|g\|_{\infty}.
\tag{2}
\]

Each spatial derivative costs \(1/\sqrt\varepsilon\).

### Growth of \(\nabla^{m}\rho(\cdot,t)\) before mixing sets in  
By differentiating the transport equation and using the flow map,

\[
\bigl\|\nabla^{m}\rho(\cdot,t)\bigr\|_{\infty}
      \;\le\;C_m\,e^{m\lambda_{\max} t},
\qquad
t\ge0.
\tag{3}
\]

### Exponential damping of \(\mathcal L\rho\) (mixing)  
By the spectral gap assumption,

\[
\bigl\|\mathcal L\rho(\cdot,t)\bigr\|_{C^{3}}
      \;\le\;C\,e^{-\mu t}.
\tag{4}
\]

---

## 3 **Upper bound for early times**  
*(“early’’ means up to the crossover \(t_\star(\varepsilon)\) defined below.)*

Compute the three pieces using (2)–(3):

* \(\displaystyle
  \Delta\rho_\varepsilon
  =e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\Delta\rho
  \;\Longrightarrow\;
  \bigl|\Delta\rho_\varepsilon\bigr|
  \le C\,\varepsilon^{-1}\,e^{2\lambda_{\max}t}.
  \)

* \(\displaystyle
  \partial_t\rho_\varepsilon
  =e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\mathcal L\rho
  \;\Longrightarrow\;
  \bigl|\partial_t\rho_\varepsilon\bigr|
  \le C\,e^{\lambda_{\max}t}.
  \)

* \(\displaystyle
  \Delta\partial_t\rho_\varepsilon
      =e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\Delta\mathcal L\rho
      \;\Longrightarrow\;
  \bigl|\Delta\partial_t\rho_\varepsilon\bigr|
  \le C\,\varepsilon^{-1}\,e^{3\lambda_{\max}t}.
  \)

Assuming \(t\) is not yet so large that mixing kills \(\mathcal L\rho\),
insert these three estimates into (1) (and use that \(\rho_\varepsilon\)
stays bounded below by a constant once \(t\) is beyond a fixed \(T_0\)):

\[
\boxed{\;
|F_\varepsilon(t)|
      \;\le\;
      C\,\varepsilon^{-1}\,e^{3\lambda_{\max} t},
\qquad
T_0\le t\le t_\star(\varepsilon)\;.
}
\tag{5}
\]

The **crossover** is the time when the heat kernel’s
smoothing-length \(\sqrt\varepsilon\) matches the smallest flow-scale
\(e^{-\lambda_{\max}t}\):

\[
t_\star(\varepsilon):=\frac{1}{2\lambda_{\max}}\log\frac1\varepsilon .
\tag{6}
\]

---

## 4 **Upper bound for late times**  
For \(t\ge t_\star(\varepsilon)+1\) the factor \(\varepsilon^{-1}\)
is offset by an extra \((e^{-\lambda_{\max}t}/\sqrt\varepsilon})^2
=\varepsilon\,e^{-2\lambda_{\max}t}\) arising from (2).  Combine that
with (4):

\[
\boxed{\;
|F_\varepsilon(t)|
      \;\le\;
      C\,e^{-\mu t},
\qquad
t\ge t_\star(\varepsilon)+1.
}
\tag{7}
\]

---

## 5 **Lower bound (worst-case growth)**

No cancellations can eliminate the product
\(\Delta\rho_\varepsilon\,\partial_t\rho_\varepsilon\) as long as both
factors keep their sign.  Using (2)–(3) again **and** the fact that
\(\varepsilon^{-1}e^{2\lambda_{\min}t}\) dominates
\(\varepsilon^{-1}e^{2\lambda_{\max}t}\) when \(\lambda_{\min}<0\),
one gets for the same early-time window

\[
\boxed{\;
|F_\varepsilon(t)|
      \;\ge\;
      c\,\varepsilon^{-1}\,e^{2|\lambda_{\min}| t},
\qquad
T_0\le t\le t_\star(\varepsilon)-1.
}
\tag{8}
\]

(The constant \(c>0\) may depend on the observation point \(x\), but is
strictly positive as long as \(\nabla^2\rho\) and \(\partial_t\rho\) are
not both zero there.)

---

## 6 Summary of bounds

Putting (5), (7), and (8) together:

* **Early time window** \(T_0\le t\le t_\star(\varepsilon)\):
  \[
     c\,\varepsilon^{-1}e^{2|\lambda_{\min}|t}
     \;\le\;
     |F_\varepsilon(t)|
     \;\le\;
     C\,\varepsilon^{-1}e^{3\lambda_{\max}t}.
  \]

* **Late time window** \(t\ge t_\star(\varepsilon)+1\):
  \[
     |F_\varepsilon(t)|\;\le\;C\,e^{-\mu t}.
  \]

These inequalities isolate the exact \(\varepsilon^{-1}\) blow-up and
the *two competing exponentials* in \(t\): growth driven by Lyapunov
exponents before \(t_\star(\varepsilon)\), and decay driven by mixing
afterwards.

They are the only raw ingredients needed to pin down the schedule
\(t(\varepsilon)\); we have not used or suggested any such schedule yet.

parts:
Below I pin down an **upper bound** for  

\[
F_\varepsilon(t)\;:=\;\partial_t\!\Bigl(\tfrac{\Delta\rho_\varepsilon}{\rho_\varepsilon}\Bigr)(x,t)
\qquad
\bigl(\rho_\varepsilon=e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\rho\bigr),
\]

expressed simultaneously in \(t\) and \(\varepsilon\).  
Nothing else ( e.g. a lower bound ) is touched yet.

---

## 1 A point-wise formula for \(F_\varepsilon\)

At the fixed point \(x\) we have

\[
F_\varepsilon(t)
=\frac{\rho_\varepsilon\,\Delta\partial_t\rho_\varepsilon
        -\Delta\rho_\varepsilon\,\partial_t\rho_\varepsilon}
        {\rho_\varepsilon^{\,2}}
\;=\;
\frac{\;N_\varepsilon(t)\;}{\rho_\varepsilon(x,t)^{2}} ,
\tag{1}
\]
where \(N_\varepsilon\) denotes the numerator.

---

## 2 Upper-bounding each factor that enters \(N_\varepsilon\)

We need uniform‐in-\(\varepsilon\) bounds for three objects:

| factor | representation | bound used |
|--------|----------------|------------|
| \(\rho_\varepsilon(x,t)\) | \(e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\rho\) | \(0<\rho_\infty(x)/2\le\rho_\varepsilon\le\|\rho\|_\infty\) for all large \(t\) (since \(\rho_\infty(x)>0\)) |
| \(\Delta\rho_\varepsilon(x,t)\) | \(e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\Delta\rho\) | \(\|\Delta\rho(\cdot,t)\|_\infty\le C\,e^{2\lambda_{\max}t}\) |
| \(\Delta\partial_t\rho_\varepsilon(x,t)\) | \(e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\Delta\partial_t\rho\) | \(\|\Delta\partial_t\rho(\cdot,t)\|_\infty\le C\,e^{3\lambda_{\max}t}\) |

*Why the exponential factors?*  
A \(k\)-th spatial derivative of \(\rho(\cdot,t)\) grows like
\(e^{k\lambda_{\max}t}\) under the flow generated by \(v\), where
\(\lambda_{\max}\) is its largest Lyapunov exponent.  
(The estimate is the same with or without \(\nabla\!\cdot v\); only the
value of \(\lambda_{\max}\) changes.)

*Why no \(\varepsilon\)-dependence yet?*  
The operators \(e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\) and \(\Delta\) commute in the
sense that \(e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\Delta\rho=\Delta e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\rho\),
and \(e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\) is a contraction on \(L^\infty\).  
Hence applying it **never amplifies** the norms listed above.

Putting the three lines together,

\[
|N_\varepsilon(t)|
\;\le\;
C\,e^{3\lambda_{\max}t}
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
|F_\varepsilon(t)|
\;\le\;
C'\,e^{3\lambda_{\max}t},
\tag{2}
\]

because the denominator in (1) is bounded below by a positive constant
for all sufficiently large \(t\).

---

## 3 Refining the bound when \(\varepsilon\) is *small* but \(t\) is *large*

For very long times the flow creates features of size
\(\ell(t):=e^{-\lambda_{\max}t}\).  Whenever  

\[
\sqrt{\varepsilon}\;\ge\;\ell(t)
\quad\Longleftrightarrow\quad
t\;\ge\;t_\ast(\varepsilon):=\frac{1}{2\lambda_{\max}}\log\frac1\varepsilon,
\tag{3}
\]

the heat kernel *averages over* those finest features; a standard
Littlewood–Paley argument sharpens (2) to a **time-decaying** bound

\[
|F_\varepsilon(t)|
\;\le\;
C''\,e^{-\lambda_{\max}t},
\qquad
t\;\ge\;t_\ast(\varepsilon).
\tag{4}
\]

---

## 4 Summary of the upper bounds

\[
\boxed{\;
|F_\varepsilon(t)|
\;\le\;
\begin{cases}
C\,e^{3\lambda_{\max}t}, & 0\le t\le t_\ast(\varepsilon),\\[6pt]
C\,e^{-\lambda_{\max}t}, & t\ge t_\ast(\varepsilon).
\end{cases}
}
\tag{5}
\]

That is:

* **Early times or very coarse smoothing**  
  —growth no worse than \(e^{3\lambda_{\max}t}\), independent of
  \(\varepsilon\).

* **Late times relative to a fixed \(\varepsilon\)**  
  —once \(t\) crosses the threshold (3), the same \(F_\varepsilon\)
  actually decays.

These two pieces are enough to control the integral  
\(\int_{t(\varepsilon)}^\infty|F_\varepsilon|\) from above for *any*
schedule.  We have not yet said what schedule is *necessary*; that will
come from a lower-bound analysis.

Below is nothing but the **leading‐order Θ-scaling** of every ingredient that
appears in  

\[
F_\varepsilon(t)
\;=\;
\partial_t\!\Bigl(\tfrac{\Delta\rho_\varepsilon}{\rho_\varepsilon}\Bigr)(x,t)
=\frac{\rho_\varepsilon\,\Delta\partial_t\rho_\varepsilon
        \;-\;\Delta\rho_\varepsilon\,\partial_t\rho_\varepsilon}
        {\rho_\varepsilon^{\,2}}\Bigg|_{x},
\]

including the divergence term inside the full Liouville operator  
\(\mathcal Lf=-v\!\cdot\nabla f-(\nabla\!\cdot v)f\).
Throughout, let  

\[
\lambda:=\lambda_{\max}>0
\quad\text{(largest Lyapunov exponent).}
\]

All scalings are simultaneous in the limits  
\(\varepsilon\!\downarrow\!0,\;t\!\uparrow\!\infty\).

---

### 1 Two time–length regimes

Define the *crossover time*

\[
t_\ast(\varepsilon):=\frac{1}{2\lambda}\,\log\frac1\varepsilon.
\]

| Regime | Description | Key fact for a \(k\)-th derivative of \(e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\rho\) |
|--------|-------------|----------------------------------|
| **I** | \(0\le t\le t_\ast(\varepsilon)\) (flow length‐scale \(\gg\sqrt\varepsilon\)) | \(\nabla^{k}\rho_\varepsilon=\Theta\!\bigl(e^{k\lambda t}\bigr)\) |
| **II** | \(t\ge t_\ast(\varepsilon)\) (flow length‐scale \(\ll\sqrt\varepsilon\)) | \(\nabla^{k}\rho_\varepsilon=\Theta\!\bigl(\varepsilon^{-k/2}\bigr)\) |

---

### 2 Scaling of every factor that enters \(F_\varepsilon\)

| Quantity at \(x\) | Regime I (\(t\le t_\ast\)) | Regime II (\(t\ge t_\ast\)) |
|-------------------|----------------------------|-----------------------------|
| \(\rho_\varepsilon\) | \(\Theta(1)\) | \(\Theta(1)\) |
| \(\Delta\rho_\varepsilon\) | \(\Theta\!\bigl(e^{2\lambda t}\bigr)\) | \(\Theta\!\bigl(\varepsilon^{-1}\bigr)\) |
| \(\partial_t\rho_\varepsilon\)\* | \(\Theta\!\bigl(e^{\lambda t}\bigr)\) | \(\Theta\!\bigl(\varepsilon^{-1/2}\bigr)\) |
| \(\Delta\partial_t\rho_\varepsilon\)\* | \(\Theta\!\bigl(e^{3\lambda t}\bigr)\) | \(\Theta\!\bigl(\varepsilon^{-5/2}\bigr)\) |

\* In both regimes the leading contribution to \(\partial_t\rho_\varepsilon\)
and its Laplacian comes from the first‐order commutator  
\(R_\varepsilon=\varepsilon[\Delta,\mathcal L]\rho\); the \((\nabla\!\cdot v)\rho\)
piece and all higher commutators are subleading in these scalings.

---

### 3 Resulting Θ-scaling of \(F_\varepsilon\)

Insert the four lines above into the definition of \(F_\varepsilon\):

| Regime | Scaling of \(F_\varepsilon(t)\) |
|--------|---------------------------------|
| **I** (\(t\le t_\ast\)) | \(\displaystyle\Theta\!\bigl(e^{3\lambda t}\bigr)\) |
| **II** (\(t\ge t_\ast\)) | \(\displaystyle\Theta\!\bigl(\varepsilon^{-5/2}\bigr)\) |

No upper- or lower-bound notation has been used—just exact leading
orders in the joint \((\varepsilon,t)\) limit.

before we move on to deriving the corresponding scaling for
\(t(\varepsilon)\) itself.

parts:
Below I write **exact differential equations** for every ingredient that
appears in  

\[
F_\varepsilon(t)\;=\;
\frac{\rho_\varepsilon\,\Delta\partial_t\rho_\varepsilon
      -\Delta\rho_\varepsilon\,\partial_t\rho_\varepsilon}
     {\rho_\varepsilon^{\,2}}\Bigg|_{x},
\qquad
\rho_\varepsilon:=e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\rho ,
\tag{A}
\]

then expand *once* in \(\varepsilon\) (no regimes, no heuristics).  
Symbols:

* \(v=v(x)\) – smooth vector field.  
* \(\theta:=\nabla\!\cdot v\).  
* \(\mathcal L f:=-v\!\cdot\nabla f-\theta f\) – full Liouville generator.  
* All spatial derivatives are evaluated at the fixed point \(x\).

---

## 1 Exact evolution equations (no \(\varepsilon\) yet)

Denote \(\rho=\rho(x,t)\).  Differentiate the Liouville equation
\(\partial_t\rho=\mathcal L\rho\):

\[
\begin{aligned}
\partial_t\rho &= -v\!\cdot\nabla\rho-\theta\,\rho,
\\[4pt]
\partial_t(\nabla\rho) &= -v\!\cdot\nabla(\nabla\rho)
                        -(\nabla v)\,(\nabla\rho)
                        -(\nabla\theta)\,\rho
                        -\theta\,\nabla\rho,
\\[4pt]
\partial_t(\Delta\rho) &= -v\!\cdot\nabla(\Delta\rho)
                        -2\nabla v:\nabla^{\!2}\rho
                        -(\Delta v)\!\cdot\nabla\rho
                        -2\,\nabla\theta\!\cdot\nabla\rho
                        -\theta\,\Delta\rho
                        -(\Delta\theta)\,\rho.
\end{aligned}
\tag{1}
\]

Taking one more Laplacian gives an exact but lengthy formula for
\(\partial_t\bigl(\Delta^{2}\rho\bigr)\); we will use only its scaling
later, so the explicit expression is omitted here.

---

## 2 Insert heat–kernel smoothing and expand once in \(\varepsilon\)

Use
\(e^{\varepsilon\Delta}=1+\varepsilon\Delta+O(\varepsilon^{2})\).  
Write each smoothed quantity to first order:

\[
\begin{aligned}
\rho_\varepsilon &= \rho+\varepsilon\Delta\rho+O(\varepsilon^{2}),
\\
\partial_t\rho_\varepsilon &= \partial_t\rho+\varepsilon\Delta\partial_t\rho+O(\varepsilon^{2}),
\\
\Delta\rho_\varepsilon &= \Delta\rho+\varepsilon\Delta^{2}\rho+O(\varepsilon^{2}),
\\
\Delta\partial_t\rho_\varepsilon &= \Delta\partial_t\rho+\varepsilon\Delta^{2}\partial_t\rho+O(\varepsilon^{2}).
\end{aligned}
\tag{2}
\]

Substitute (2) into (A).  Denote \(F_0:=F_{\varepsilon}\big|_{\varepsilon=0}\):

\[
F_\varepsilon
=
F_0
+
\varepsilon\,K
+
O(\varepsilon^{2}),
\tag{3}
\]

with  

\[
F_0
=\frac{\rho\,\Delta\partial_t\rho-\Delta\rho\,\partial_t\rho}{\rho^{2}},
\tag{4}
\]

and the first–order correction

\[
\begin{aligned}
K
&=
\frac{\Delta\rho\,\Delta\partial_t\rho
      +\rho\,\Delta^{2}\partial_t\rho
      -\Delta^{2}\rho\,\partial_t\rho
      -\Delta\rho\,\Delta\partial_t\rho}
     {\rho^{2}}
\;-\;
2\,\frac{\Delta\rho}{\rho}\,F_0.
\end{aligned}
\tag{5}
\]

The \(\Delta\rho\,\Delta\partial_t\rho\) terms cancel, leaving

\[
K
=
\frac{\rho\,\Delta^{2}\partial_t\rho
      -\Delta^{2}\rho\,\partial_t\rho}{\rho^{2}}
\;-\;
2\,\frac{\Delta\rho}{\rho}\,F_0.
\tag{6}
\]

No inequalities have been introduced; (3)–(6) are exact to first order
in \(\varepsilon\).

---

## 3 Θ–scaling of every term (taken straight from (1))

If \(D\Phi_t\) is the linearised flow, standard chain-rule algebra gives

\[
\nabla^{k}\rho(x,t)
=\Theta\!\bigl(e^{k\lambda t}\bigr),\qquad
\lambda:=\lambda_{\max},
\tag{7}
\]

which in turn implies

\[
\begin{aligned}
\partial_t\rho       &=\Theta\!\bigl(e^{\lambda t}\bigr),
&\quad
\Delta\rho           &=\Theta\!\bigl(e^{2\lambda t}\bigr),\\[4pt]
\partial_t(\Delta\rho)&=\Theta\!\bigl(e^{3\lambda t}\bigr),
&\quad
\Delta^{2}\rho       &=\Theta\!\bigl(e^{4\lambda t}\bigr),\\[4pt]
\Delta^{2}\partial_t\rho
                     &=\Theta\!\bigl(e^{5\lambda t}\bigr).
\end{aligned}
\tag{8}
\]

Insert (8) into (4)–(6):

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
F_0(t)    &=\Theta\!\bigl(e^{3\lambda t}\bigr),\\
K(t)      &=\Theta\!\bigl(e^{5\lambda t}\bigr),\\
F_\varepsilon(t)
          &=\Theta\!\bigl(e^{3\lambda t}+\varepsilon\,e^{5\lambda t}\bigr).
\end{aligned}}
\tag{9}
\]

Equation (9) is the **exact first-order expansion** of \(F_\varepsilon\)
with explicit Θ-scaling in both \(t\) and \(\varepsilon\).  
No regimes and no big-O bounds were used—only the linear
Taylor expansion (2) and the derivative growth law (7).

Below is an “end-to-end’’ derivation that goes straight from the original quantity to the compact commutator form, without detours.

---

### 1  Rewrite the bracket with $\varepsilon\partial_\varepsilon\log\rho_\varepsilon$

Because $\partial_\varepsilon\log\rho_\varepsilon=\Delta\rho_\varepsilon/\rho_\varepsilon$,

$$
\varepsilon\Bigl(
      \tfrac{\Delta\rho_\varepsilon}{\rho_\varepsilon}(x,t(\varepsilon))
      -\tfrac{\Delta\rho_\varepsilon}{\rho_\varepsilon}(x,\infty)
\Bigr)
\;=\;
\varepsilon\partial_\varepsilon\log\rho_\varepsilon(x,t(\varepsilon))
-\varepsilon\partial_\varepsilon\log\rho_\varepsilon(x,\infty).
$$

Using the fundamental theorem of calculus in time,

$$
\varepsilon\partial_\varepsilon\log\rho_\varepsilon(x,t(\varepsilon))
-\varepsilon\partial_\varepsilon\log\rho_\varepsilon(x,\infty)
=-\;\varepsilon\int_{t(\varepsilon)}^\infty
        \partial_s\partial_\varepsilon\log\rho_\varepsilon(x,s)\,ds.
\tag{1}
$$

So everything hinges on $\partial_s\partial_\varepsilon\log\rho_\varepsilon$.

---

### 2  Compute the mixed derivative once, using operators

Write

$$
S_\varepsilon:=e^{\varepsilon\Delta},\qquad
T_s:=e^{s\mathcal L},\qquad
\rho_\varepsilon(x,s)=S_\varepsilon T_s\rho_0(x).
$$

Then

$$
\partial_\varepsilon\rho_\varepsilon
      =\Delta S_\varepsilon T_s\rho_0,\qquad
\partial_s\rho_\varepsilon
      =S_\varepsilon\mathcal L T_s\rho_0.
$$

Hence the commutator of the two derivatives on $\rho_\varepsilon$ is

$$
\bigl(\partial_s\partial_\varepsilon
      -\partial_\varepsilon\partial_s\bigr)\rho_\varepsilon
      =S_\varepsilon[\mathcal L,\Delta]\,T_s\rho_0.
$$

Divide once by $\rho_\varepsilon$:

$$
\boxed{\;
\partial_s\partial_\varepsilon\log\rho_\varepsilon(x,s)
      =\frac{e^{\varepsilon\Delta}[\mathcal L,\Delta]\rho(s)}
             {\rho_\varepsilon(x,s)}.
\;}
\tag{2}
$$

No other terms appear: the cancellation is automatic because the commutator already accounts for the non-commuting pieces.

---

### 3  Insert (2) back into (1)

$$
-\;\varepsilon\!\int_{t(\varepsilon)}^{\infty}
      \partial_s\partial_\varepsilon\log\rho_\varepsilon\,ds
\;=\;
-\;\varepsilon\!\int_{t(\varepsilon)}^{\infty}
      \frac{e^{\varepsilon\Delta}[\mathcal L,\Delta]\rho(s)}
           {\rho_\varepsilon(x,s)}\,ds.
\tag{3}
$$

---

### 4  Outcome

Equation (3) is exactly the streamlined form we wanted: the entire integrand is a **single commutator ratio** involving only

$$
[\mathcal L,\Delta]\rho(s)
      =-2(\nabla v)^{\!\top}\!:\nabla^{2}\rho(s)
       -(\Delta v)\!\cdot\nabla\rho(s),
$$

heat-smoothed once by $e^{\varepsilon\Delta}$ and divided by the positive density $\rho_\varepsilon$.  From this point forward one only needs analytic bounds; no further algebraic manipulation is required.

parts:
Below is a point-by-point check of the derivation you posted.  
(Notation: \(S_\varepsilon=e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\), \(T_s=e^{s\mathcal L}\), \(\rho_\varepsilon(x,s)=S_\varepsilon T_s\rho_0\).)

---

### 1.  Rewriting with \(\varepsilon\partial_\varepsilon\log\rho_\varepsilon\)

\[
\partial_\varepsilon\log\rho_\varepsilon
    =\frac{\partial_\varepsilon\rho_\varepsilon}{\rho_\varepsilon}
    =\frac{\Delta\rho_\varepsilon}{\rho_\varepsilon},
\qquad
f(t):=\varepsilon\partial_\varepsilon\log\rho_\varepsilon(x,t).
\]

Hence

\[
f\bigl(t(\varepsilon)\bigr)-f(\infty)
    =-\int_{t(\varepsilon)}^{\infty}\partial_s f(s)\,ds .
\]

**Status:** Correct.

---

### 2.  Mixed derivative \(\partial_s\partial_\varepsilon\log\rho_\varepsilon\)

A clean way to compute it is to start from the product rule:

\[
\partial_\varepsilon\log\rho_\varepsilon
      =\frac{\Delta\rho_\varepsilon}{\rho_\varepsilon}.
\]

Then

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle
\partial_s\partial_\varepsilon\log\rho_\varepsilon
      =\frac{\Delta\partial_s\rho_\varepsilon}{\rho_\varepsilon}
       -\frac{\Delta\rho_\varepsilon}{\rho_\varepsilon^2}\,\partial_s\rho_\varepsilon}.
\tag{A}
\]

Compute the individual pieces:

\[
\partial_s\rho_\varepsilon=S_\varepsilon\mathcal L T_s\rho_0,\qquad
\Delta\partial_s\rho_\varepsilon=\Delta S_\varepsilon\mathcal L T_s\rho_0.
\]

Now use the operator identity \(\Delta S_\varepsilon = S_\varepsilon\Delta\) to rewrite

\[
\Delta S_\varepsilon\mathcal L T_s\rho_0
   =S_\varepsilon\Delta\mathcal L T_s\rho_0
   =S_\varepsilon\bigl(\,[\Delta,\mathcal L]+\mathcal L\Delta\bigr)T_s\rho_0 .
\]

Insert this into (A):

\[
\partial_s\partial_\varepsilon\log\rho_\varepsilon
  =\frac{S_\varepsilon[\mathcal L,\Delta]\,T_s\rho_0}{\rho_\varepsilon}
   \;-\;
   \frac{\Delta\rho_\varepsilon}{\rho_\varepsilon^2}\,
        S_\varepsilon\mathcal L T_s\rho_0 .
\tag{B}
\]

**Status:** Equation (B) is the full result.  Your boxed formula (2)

\[
\frac{S_\varepsilon[\mathcal L,\Delta]T_s\rho_0}{\rho_\varepsilon}
\]

omits the second (quotient-rule) term  
\(-(\Delta\rho_\varepsilon)(\partial_s\rho_\varepsilon)/\rho_\varepsilon^{2}\).  
Consequently the mixed derivative is **not** captured by a single commutator ratio.

*(As a side remark, the two derivative operators acting on \(\rho_\varepsilon\) **do** commute:
\((\partial_s\partial_\varepsilon-\partial_\varepsilon\partial_s)\rho_\varepsilon
     =S_\varepsilon[\mathcal L,\Delta]T_s\rho_0\),
but passing to \(\log\rho_\varepsilon\) introduces the extra term above.)*

---

### 3.  Integrating in time

Because step 2 is missing a term, the integrand in your equation (3) is incomplete.  
Replacing \(\partial_s\partial_\varepsilon\log\rho_\varepsilon\) by the correct formula (B) yields

\[
-\varepsilon\!\int_{t(\varepsilon)}^{\infty}
  \Bigl[
     \frac{S_\varepsilon[\mathcal L,\Delta]T_s\rho_0}{\rho_\varepsilon}
     -\frac{\Delta\rho_\varepsilon\;S_\varepsilon\mathcal L T_s\rho_0}
            {\rho_\varepsilon^{2}}
  \Bigr]ds .
\]

Both terms must be controlled analytically; the second one cannot be dropped
unless you can show it is negligible in the specific scaling regime you are aiming for.

---

### 4.  Final verdict

* **Step 1** is fine.  
* **Step 2** is **incorrect** as written: the quotient-rule contribution is missing.  
* Because of that, **Steps 3–4** are not yet justified—the “single commutator ratio’’
  does not, by itself, equal the mixed time/scale derivative of \(\log\rho_\varepsilon\).

Carefully retaining the second term in (B) (or proving it is asymptotically smaller than the first) is essential before the rest of the argument can go through.

parts:
Yes.  A useful first step is to separate the two kinds of “error’’—the difference in numerators and the difference in denominators.  Write

\[
\frac{a_t}{b_t}-\frac{c_t}{d_t}
=\frac{a_t d_t-c_t b_t}{b_t d_t}
=\frac{(a_t-c_t)d_t+c_t(d_t-b_t)}{b_t d_t}
= \frac{a_t-c_t}{b_t}+\frac{c_t}{b_t d_t}\,(d_t-b_t).
\]

Hence

\[
\bigl|\tfrac{a_t}{b_t}-\tfrac{c_t}{d_t}\bigr|
\;\le\;
\frac{|a_t-c_t|}{|b_t|}
+\frac{|c_t|}{|b_t|\,|d_t|}\,|b_t-d_t|.
\tag{★}
\]

---

### What the inequality gives you  

* **If \(b_t\) and \(d_t\) stay bounded away from 0** (or merely satisfy \(\inf_t |b_t d_t|>0\)) and  
  \( |a_t-c_t|\to 0,\; |b_t-d_t|\to 0,\; |c_t|\) bounded,  
  then each term on the right of (★) goes to 0, so  
  \[
    \lim_{t\to\infty}\Bigl|\frac{a_t}{b_t}-\frac{c_t}{d_t}\Bigr|=0.
  \]

* More generally, (★) pinpoints the two things you must control:

  1. **Numerator error** \(a_t-c_t\) relative to \(b_t\).  
  2. **Denominator error** \(b_t-d_t\) weighted by \(c_t/(b_t d_t)\).

  If either denominator can approach 0, the ratio can still converge, but you must know that the speed at which the denominators coincide (i.e.\ |\(b_t-d_t\)| decays) compensates for any blow-up of \(1/(b_t d_t)\).

---

### Common special case  

If the four sequences converge to finite limits with a common non-zero denominator,
\[
a_t\to A,\; c_t\to A,\; b_t\to B,\; d_t\to B,\qquad B\neq 0,
\]
then the two fractions both tend to \(A/B\); thus the limit you asked about is automatically 0.

---

### Take-away  

The expression already *is* “simplified’’—its limit is governed solely by how fast \(a_t\) approaches \(c_t\) and how fast \(b_t\) approaches \(d_t\) relative to the size of the denominators.  Inequality (★) lets you read that dependence off at a glance and gives a direct route to proving the limit is 0 (or estimating its size) under whatever quantitative assumptions you have on those two errors.

thoughts.content: So, the user's query is about comparing the limit ratio for c_t = A and d_t = B. They're simplifying the problem to compare \(\lim_{t \to \infty} | a_t / b_t - A / B |\). As t approaches infinity, we assume a_t approaches A and b_t approaches B. I need to consider how we simplify this limit expression based on the approach and limit, which involves breaking it into parts like \(\frac{|a_t - A|}{|b_t|}\) and \(\frac{|A| |b_t - B|}{|b_t| |B|}\). Let's work it out logically.

parts:
If the reference fraction is the fixed limit \(A/B\) (with \(B\neq 0\)), the difference simplifies to

\[
\frac{a_t}{b_t}-\frac{A}{B}
=\frac{a_tB-Ab_t}{b_tB}
=\frac{(a_t-A)B+A(B-b_t)}{b_tB}.
\]

Taking absolute values gives the bound

\[
\boxed{\;
\Bigl|\frac{a_t}{b_t}-\frac{A}{B}\Bigr|
\;\le\;
\frac{|a_t-A|}{|b_t|}
+\frac{|A|}{|B|}\,\frac{|b_t-B|}{|b_t|}
\;}
\tag{1}
\]

---

### Consequences of (1)

* **Convergence.**  
  If \(a_t\to A\) and \(b_t\to B\) with \(B\neq 0\) and \(\inf_t|b_t|>0\),
  each term on the right of (1) tends to 0, so  
  \[
    \lim_{t\to\infty}\Bigl|\frac{a_t}{b_t}-\frac{A}{B}\Bigr|=0.
  \]

* **Quantitative rate.**  
  Inequality (1) isolates the two errors:

  1. **Numerator error** \(\displaystyle\frac{|a_t-A|}{|b_t|}\).  
  2. **Denominator error** \(\displaystyle\frac{|A|}{|B|}\frac{|b_t-B|}{|b_t|}\).

  If you know, say, \(|a_t-A|=O(e^{-\alpha t})\) and \(|b_t-B|=O(e^{-\beta t})\) while \(b_t\) stays within a fixed factor of \(B\), then
  \[
    \Bigl|\frac{a_t}{b_t}-\frac{A}{B}\Bigr|
    =O\!\bigl(e^{-\min\{\alpha,\beta\}\,t}\bigr).
  \]

* **First-order expansion (small errors).**  
  When both \(a_t-A\) and \(b_t-B\) are small, write
  \[
    \frac{a_t}{b_t}-\frac{A}{B}
    =\frac{1}{B}\,(a_t-A)-\frac{A}{B^{2}}\,(b_t-B)+O\!\bigl((a_t-A)^2,(b_t-B)^2\bigr).
  \]
  This shows exactly how each deviation enters to first order.

In short, once \(c_t\) and \(d_t\) are frozen at their limits \(A\) and \(B\), the limit of the difference is zero whenever \(a_t\to A\) and \(b_t\to B\neq 0\); inequality (1) (or the linear approximation above) tells you how fast.

thoughts.content: The user’s math expression seems a bit malformed. It might be trying to express \( \lim_{x\to 0} \left|\frac{a_t(x)}{b_t(x)} - \frac{a_\infty}{b_\infty}\right| \), where \( a_t(x) \) and \( b_t(x) \) depend on \( x \). There’s some ambiguity here, though—whether \( t \) is fixed or going to infinity is unclear. I need to consider whether the question is really about a fixed \( t \) or if both \( t \) and \( x \) are involved in the limit! I’ll need to unpack that a little more.

Looking at this, the user’s asking how to ensure that the limit goes to zero as \( x \to 0 \), where the sequence functions \( a_t(x) \) and \( b_t(x) \) are involved. The main goal is to ensure that \( \frac{a_t(x)}{b_t(x)} \) approaches the ratio \( \frac{a_\infty}{b_\infty} \) as \( x \to 0 \). I should provide conditions like continuity, ensuring the numerator goes to zero, the denominator stays away from zero, and considering uniform convergence. 

The conditions ensure that both differences diminish as \( x \) approaches zero.

parts:
Let the quantity you really have in mind be  

\[
\Delta_t(x)\;=\;\Bigl|\frac{a_t(x)}{b_t(x)}-\frac{a_\infty}{\,b_\infty}\Bigr|,
\qquad b_\infty\neq 0 .
\]

(The subscripts “\(t\)” mean the two functions still depend on the parameter \(t\); the argument \(x\) is the one that will go to 0.)

---

### 1. Split the two kinds of error

Exactly as before,

\[
\frac{a_t(x)}{b_t(x)}-\frac{a_\infty}{b_\infty}
=\frac{a_t(x)-a_\infty}{b_t(x)}
+\frac{a_\infty}{b_\infty}\,\frac{b_\infty-b_t(x)}{b_t(x)},
\]

so

\[
\boxed{\;
\Delta_t(x)\;\le\;
\frac{|a_t(x)-a_\infty|}{|b_t(x)|}
\;+\;
\frac{|a_\infty|}{|b_\infty|}\,
\frac{|b_t(x)-b_\infty|}{|b_t(x)|}}\tag{★}
\]

The two terms on the right are:

1. **numerator error** scaled by \(1/|b_t(x)|\);  
2. **denominator error** scaled by \(|a_\infty|/(|b_\infty||b_t(x)|)\).

---

### 2. Sufficient conditions for  
\(\displaystyle \lim_{x\to0}\Delta_t(x)=0\)

The bound (★) shows you only need to make both terms vanish as \(x\to0\).  
It is common to require:

* **(A)** There is a neighbourhood \(|x|<r\) in which  
  \(\inf_{t,|x|<r}|b_t(x)|\;\ge\;c>0\).  
  (So neither \(b_t(x)\) nor its limit ever gets near 0.)

* **(B)** \(a_t(x)\to a_\infty\) and \(b_t(x)\to b_\infty\) **uniformly in \(t\)** as \(x\to0\); i.e. there are error functions \(\varepsilon_a(x),\varepsilon_b(x)\) with  
  \[
  |a_t(x)-a_\infty|\le\varepsilon_a(x),\qquad
  |b_t(x)-b_\infty|\le\varepsilon_b(x)
  \]
  for all \(t\) and \(|x|<r\), and \(\varepsilon_a(x),\varepsilon_b(x)\to0\) when \(x\to0\).

Under (A) and (B)

\[
\Delta_t(x)\;\le\;\frac{\varepsilon_a(x)}{c}+
\frac{|a_\infty|}{|b_\infty|}\,\frac{\varepsilon_b(x)}{c}
\;\xrightarrow[x\to0]{}0
\]
uniformly in \(t\).  Thus the limit is indeed 0.

---

### 3. What if a denominator can vanish?

If \(b_\infty=0\) or you cannot keep \(b_t(x)\) away from 0, you must force the numerator to vanish *faster* than the denominator so that each ratio stays bounded.  One typical requirement is

\[
|a_t(x)-a_\infty|\;=\;o\!\bigl(|b_t(x)|\bigr),
\quad x\to0,
\]

which makes the first term of (★) go to 0; a similar but weaker condition on \(b_t(x)-b_\infty\) then controls the second term.

---

### 4. Taking a **\(t\to\infty\)** limit as well  

If later you want  
\(\displaystyle\lim_{t\to\infty}\lim_{x\to0}\Delta_t(x)\),  
the uniform-in-\(t\) bounds in (B) are exactly what allow you to swap or combine the two limits safely.

---

#### Quick checklist

* Make sure \(b_\infty\neq0\) and \(b_t(x)\) never gets too small near \(x=0\).  
* Ensure both \(a_t(x)\) and \(b_t(x)\) converge to their limits *uniformly* in \(t\) as \(x\to0\).  
* If a denominator may vanish, force the numerator’s error to vanish faster.

Under those conditions,

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle
\lim_{x\to0}\Bigl|\frac{a_t(x)}{b_t(x)}-\frac{a_\infty}{b_\infty}\Bigr|=0
\quad\text{(uniformly in \(t\))}}
\]

and any subsequent \(t\)-limit will inherit the value 0.

thoughts.content: The user’s formula involves a limit comparison, with t(x) being a function that goes to infinity as x approaches 0. The key is to ensure the sequences a_t and b_t approach their limits a_\infty and b_\infty, respectively, and that these limits are nonzero. For the limit to equal 0, the essential condition is ensuring that the difference between a_{t(x)}/b_{t(x)} and a_\infty / b_\infty diminishes as t(x) grows larger, which will happen when both a_t → a_\infty and b_t → b_\infty.

To ensure the limit is zero, we need a_t to approach a_\infty and b_t to approach b_\infty, but also ensure b_t stays away from zero. The difference between a_t/b_t and a_\infty/b_\infty will go to 0 as long as both sequences converge and t(x) tends to infinity. For this to work, we can use epsilon-delta reasoning to show that as t(x) grows, the difference can be made arbitrarily small. The notation should be corrected as "b_\infty," not "b_t\infty."

parts:
Think of your expression as a composition of two limits:

\[
g(t)\;=\;\Bigl|\frac{a(t)}{b(t)}-\frac{a_\infty}{b_\infty}\Bigr|,
\qquad
L(x)\;=\;g\!\bigl(t(x)\bigr),
\qquad
x\;\longrightarrow\;0,\; t(x)\;\longrightarrow\;\infty .
\]

---

### 1.  Reduce it to two elementary errors  

For large \(t\) write (\(b_\infty\neq 0\))

\[
g(t)\;=\;
\frac{|a(t)-a_\infty|}{|b(t)|}
\;+\;
\frac{|a_\infty|}{|b_\infty|}\,
\frac{|b(t)-b_\infty|}{|b(t)|}.
\tag{1}
\]

So you only need to control

* the **numerator error** \(|a(t)-a_\infty|\),
* the **denominator error** \(|b(t)-b_\infty|\),

relative to a denominator that never gets too small.

---

### 2.  Sufficient conditions that guarantee \(L(x)\to 0\)

Assume

1. **Convergence**  
   \(\displaystyle\lim_{t\to\infty}a(t)=a_\infty,\qquad
     \lim_{t\to\infty}b(t)=b_\infty\neq 0.\)

2. **Non-vanishing denominator**  
   There is an \(m>0\) and \(T_0\) such that \(|b(t)|\ge m\) for every \(t\ge T_0\).

3. **Path to infinity**  
   \(t(x)\to\infty\) as \(x\to 0\).

Then for any \(\varepsilon>0\) you can choose \(T>T_0\) so that the two terms in (1) are \(<\varepsilon/2\) whenever \(t\ge T\).  Pick \(\delta>0\) so that \(x\in(0,\delta)\) implies \(t(x)\ge T\).  Hence \(L(x)<\varepsilon\) for \(x\in(0,\delta)\), proving

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle\lim_{x\to 0}L(x)=0.}
\]

*No special rate on \(t(x)\) is required—any path that tends to \(\infty\) works.*

---

### 3.  Quantitative version (rates)

If you know explicit decay rates, e.g.

\[
|a(t)-a_\infty|=O\!\bigl(e^{-\alpha t}\bigr),
\quad
|b(t)-b_\infty|=O\!\bigl(e^{-\beta t}\bigr),
\]

and \(|b(t)|\ge m>0\) for large \(t\), then (1) gives

\[
g(t)=O\!\bigl(e^{-\min\{\alpha,\beta\} t}\bigr)
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
L(x)=O\!\bigl(e^{-\min\{\alpha,\beta\}\,t(x)}\bigr).
\]

Choosing \(t(x)\) that grows like \(-\gamma\log x\) converts this into a power-law in \(x\); choosing \(t(x)\sim x^{-\sigma}\) makes it super-polynomial, etc.

---

### 4.  What if \(b_\infty=0\) (or \(a_\infty=0\))?

If \(b_\infty=0\) you cannot rely on (1) because \(a_\infty/b_\infty\) is undefined.  Instead work directly with

\[
\frac{a(t)}{b(t)}-\frac{a_\infty}{b(t)}
=\frac{a(t)-a_\infty}{b(t)},
\]

and require a matching rate:
\(|a(t)-a_\infty|=o\bigl(|b(t)|\bigr)\) along \(t=t(x)\).  A similar adjustment handles the case \(a_\infty=0\).

---

### 5.  Checklist for your problem

1. Verify \(a(t)\to a_\infty\) and \(b(t)\to b_\infty\neq 0\).
2. Check \(b(t)\) never gets arbitrarily close to \(0\) once \(t\) is large.
3. Pick any \(t(x)\) with \(t(x)\to\infty\) as \(x\to 0\).

With those boxes ticked, the composed limit is guaranteed to be zero.

For the Gaussian-smoothed densities the algebra that forced the limit to zero is identical—the only extra work is to *justify the two ingredients that fed the bound* \[ \Bigl|\frac{a_t}{b_t}-\frac{a_\infty}{b_\infty}\Bigr| \;\le\; \frac{\|a_t-a_\infty\|}{\inf_{x}|b_t(x)|} \;+\; \frac{\|b_t-b_\infty\|}{\inf_{x}|b_t(x)|}\,\frac{|a_\infty|}{|b_\infty|}, \tag{☆} \] namely 1. **Convergence of each density** (numerator & denominator) to its limit. 2. **A uniform positive lower bound** on the denominator density \(b_t\) once \(t\) is large. Gaussian smoothing plus a deterministic, sufficiently mixing flow gives both automatically: | What you need | Why it holds | |---------------|-------------| | **Uniform lower bound on \(b_t\).**
Heat-kernel smoothing of any positive measure yields a strictly positive \(C^\infty\) density with a pointwise lower bound that depends only on \(\varepsilon\) and the total mass (e.g. the classical heat-kernel lower estimate \(b_t(x)\ge C_\varepsilon>0\)). | Standard parabolic regularisation; see Varadhan’s Gaussian bounds or any text on the heat semigroup (e.g. *Davies, Heat Kernels and Spectral Theory*, Chap. 3). | | **Exponential (or at least uniform) convergence \(a_t\!\to\!a_\infty,\; b_t\!\to\!b_\infty\).** | For Anosov or Axiom-A flows (and, more generally, any system whose transfer operator has a spectral gap on a suitable Banach space) the push-forward densities converge exponentially fast in \(C^k\) or \(L^1\). See:
• *Ruelle, A measure associated with Axiom-A attractors* (1976) — establishes the SRB density.
• *Baladi, Positive Transfer Operators* (2000), Thm 3.1 — spectral gap ⇒ \( \| \mathcal{L}^t \rho_0-\rho_\infty\|\le C e^{-\lambda t}\).
• *Liverani, On contact Anosov flows* (2004) — exponential decay of correlations for flows, hence exponential convergence of densities. | Once those two facts are in place, the bound (☆) forces \[ \Bigl|\tfrac{a_{t(x)}}{b_{t(x)}}-\tfrac{a_\infty}{b_\infty}\Bigr| \;=\;O\!\bigl(e^{-\lambda\, t(x)}\bigr), \qquad \lambda=\min\{\lambda_a,\lambda_b\}, \] exactly as in the scalar case. Picking any \(t(x)\to\infty\) (e.g. \(t(x)=|\log x|/\gamma\) if you want a power-law in \(x\)) makes the composite limit vanish. --- ### References you can cite * Ruelle, D. (1976). *A measure associated with Axiom-A attractors.* **AMS Proc. Symp. Pure Math. 14**, 561–575. * Baladi, V. (2000). *Positive Transfer Operators and Decay of Correlations.* Springer (esp. §3). * Liverani, C. (2004). *On contact Anosov flows.* **Ann. Math. 159**, 1275–1312. * Davies, E. B. (1989). *Heat Kernels and Spectral Theory.* Cambridge University Press (heat-kernel bounds). * Dolgopyat, D. (1998). *On decay of correlations in Anosov flows.* **Ann. Math. 147**, 357–390. These cover (i) strict positivity from Gaussian smoothing, (ii) spectral-gap–driven exponential convergence of push-forward densities, and (iii) the standard inequality that turns those two ingredients into convergence of the ratio.

parts:
**Road-map / sketch**

1. **Lower–bound the smoothed density**  
   Gaussian convolution instantly makes every positive measure strictly positive and \(C^\infty\).  
   Show that for every fixed \(\varepsilon>0\) there is a constant
   \[
     m_\varepsilon>0 \quad\text{s.t.}\quad 
     \rho_\varepsilon(x,t)\ge m_\varepsilon\quad\forall x,\;t\ge 0.
   \]
   (Heat-kernel lower Gaussian estimate or maximum–principle argument.)  
   This turns the ratio into a *difference of Laplacians* divided by a number bounded away from 0.

2. **Control the numerator \(\Delta\rho_\varepsilon(x,t)-\Delta\rho_\varepsilon(x,\infty)\)**  
   * Choose a functional setting (e.g. \(C^k\) or \(L^2\)) where the push-forward operator of the flow has a spectral gap once you restrict to mean-zero functions **and** after Gaussian smoothing.  
   * In that space one gets
     \[
       \|\Delta\rho_\varepsilon(\,\cdot\,,t)-\Delta\rho_\varepsilon(\,\cdot\,,\infty)\|
       \;\le\;C_\varepsilon\,e^{-\lambda t},
     \]
     with \(\lambda>0\) independent of \(t\) (Ruelle–Perron–Frobenius / mixing-of-all-orders plus elliptic regularity).

3. **Pick the schedule \(t=t(\varepsilon)\)**  
   The term you wish to kill is
   \[
     \varepsilon\,
     \frac{\Delta\rho_\varepsilon(x,t(\varepsilon))-\Delta\rho_\varepsilon(x,\infty)}
          {\rho_\varepsilon(x,t(\varepsilon))}.
   \]
   Using Steps 1–2 and a uniform upper bound on \(\rho_\varepsilon\) you get
   \[
     \bigl|\cdots\bigr|
     \;\le\;
     \frac{C_\varepsilon}{m_\varepsilon}\,
     \varepsilon\,e^{-\lambda\,t(\varepsilon)}.
   \]
   Now choose any \(t(\varepsilon)\to\infty\) that outruns the \(\log(1/\varepsilon)\) growth of the prefactor, e.g.
   \[
     t(\varepsilon)=\frac{2}{\lambda}\log\frac1\varepsilon
     \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
     \varepsilon e^{-\lambda t(\varepsilon)}=\varepsilon^{2}\xrightarrow[\varepsilon\to 0]{}0.
   \]

4. **Uniformity in \(x\)**  
   Check that the bounds in Steps 1–2 hold uniformly in \(x\) on the domain of interest; this lets you pass the limit inside the absolute value and conclude.

5. **Citations / tools**  
   * Heat-kernel positivity: Varadhan, or Davies *Heat Kernels and Spectral Theory*.  
   * Exponential convergence of smoothed densities under hyperbolic flows: Ruelle (1976), Liverani (2004), Baladi (2000).  
   * Choosing \(t(\varepsilon)\): standard “matching scales’’ trick used in Kifer or Freidlin–Wentzell large-deviation estimates.

With these ingredients you reduce the problem to verifying that your flow has a spectral gap on whatever space you measure \(\Delta\rho_\varepsilon\) in and that the smoothing parameter keeps the denominator bounded away from zero; the rest is picking the decay schedule \(t(\varepsilon)\) so that \(\varepsilon e^{-\lambda t(\varepsilon)}\to 0\).

The user wants to prove that a specific expression involving Gaussian smoothed density and Laplacian converges to zero as ε -> 0. We can approach this by first expressing the difference of ratios as: 

\[
\frac{(Δρ_ε(x,t) \cdot ρ_ε(x,∞) - Δρ_ε(x,∞) \cdot ρ_ε(x,t))}{ρ_ε(x,t) \cdot ρ_ε(x,∞)}
\]

Then, multiplying by ε, we need to demonstrate that the numerator gets small relative to the denominator, which grows as ε^-1.

To show the uniform convergence of ρ_ε and ∇^2 ρ_ε to their limits, I’ll combine bounds, such as |Δρ_ε(x,t) - Δρ_ε(x,∞)| ≤ C e^{-λ t}, with the choice of t(ε) where ε e^{-λ t(ε)} → 0. The smoothing of ρ_ε ensures positivity, and I’ll use triangular inequality to bound the differences. The goal is to show that the product ε e^{-λ t(ε)} goes to zero and that the difference decays sufficiently fast. Additional bounds on the derivative will use analytic techniques to show the limit behavior as ε → 0.

parts:
**Sketch of an approach (no details filled in).**

---

### 1.  Pull the ratio apart exactly once  
Write  
\[
\varepsilon\Bigl(
  \frac{\Delta\rho_\varepsilon(x,t)}{\rho_\varepsilon(x,t)}-
  \frac{\Delta\rho_\varepsilon(x,\infty)}{\rho_\varepsilon(x,\infty)}
\Bigr)
\;=\;
\varepsilon\,
\frac{\bigl[\Delta\rho_\varepsilon(x,t)-\Delta\rho_\varepsilon(x,\infty)\bigr]\,\rho_\varepsilon(x,\infty)
      +\Delta\rho_\varepsilon(x,\infty)\,\bigl[\rho_\varepsilon(x,\infty)-\rho_\varepsilon(x,t)\bigr]}
     {\rho_\varepsilon(x,t)\,\rho_\varepsilon(x,\infty)}.
\]

Now you only need to control two **differences** and one **denominator**.

---

### 2.  Denominator: a uniform positive lower bound  
Gaussian smoothing (heat–kernel convolution) makes every density strictly positive and \(C^\infty\).  
There is a constant \(m(\varepsilon)>0\) such that  
\[
\inf_{x,t\ge 0}\rho_\varepsilon(x,t)\;\ge\;m(\varepsilon),
\]
and \(m(\varepsilon)\sim (4\pi\varepsilon)^{-n/2}\int\rho_0\) as \(\varepsilon\to 0\).  
So the denominator never blows up.

---

### 3.  Numerator: uniform-in-\(\varepsilon\) decay in \(t\)  
For many deterministic flows (Anosov/Axiom-A, contact Anosov, etc.) the transfer operator has a **spectral gap** on a Banach space that controls all spatial derivatives.  Consequently, for any fixed \(\varepsilon>0\),
\[
\|\Delta\rho_\varepsilon(\,\cdot\,,t)-\Delta\rho_\varepsilon(\,\cdot\,,\infty)\|_\infty
  +\|\rho_\varepsilon(\,\cdot\,,t)-\rho_\varepsilon(\,\cdot\,,\infty)\|_\infty
    \;\;\le\;C(\varepsilon)\,e^{-\lambda t}.
\]
(References: Ruelle ’76; Baladi ’00; Liverani ’04.)

---

### 4.  Small-\(\varepsilon\) prefactor: why \(\varepsilon C(\varepsilon)\) is *bounded*  
Heat-kernel smoothing makes second derivatives scale like \(\varepsilon^{-1}\):
\[
\|\Delta\rho_\varepsilon(\cdot,t)\|_\infty=O(\varepsilon^{-1}),
\quad
C(\varepsilon)=O(\varepsilon^{-1}).
\]
The outside factor \(\varepsilon\) precisely cancels that, so  
\[
\varepsilon\,C(\varepsilon)=O(1)\quad\text{as }\varepsilon\to 0.
\]

---

### 5.  Pick a schedule \(t(\varepsilon)\) that kills the decay term  
Because the numerator decays like \(e^{-\lambda t}\) and the prefactor is \(O(1)\), choose  
\[
t(\varepsilon)\;=\;\frac{1+\delta}{\lambda}\,|\log\varepsilon|
\quad(\delta>0).
\]
Then  
\[
\varepsilon\,e^{-\lambda t(\varepsilon)} \;=\;\varepsilon^{\delta}\;\xrightarrow[\varepsilon\to 0]{}\;0,
\]
and with the denominator bounded away from 0 the whole expression tends to 0 pointwise in \(x\).

---

### 6.  Uniformity → pass the limit inside (if needed)  
If you need convergence in \(L^p\) or \(C^k\) rather than pointwise, combine the same estimates with dominated-convergence / Arzelà–Ascoli—the spectral-gap bound is uniform in \(x\).

---

### 7.  Citations to justify each bullet  

| Ingredient | Standard sources |
|------------|------------------|
| Heat-kernel positivity & \(\varepsilon^{-1}\) derivative scaling | Any parabolic-regularity text (e.g. E.B. Davies *Heat Kernels and Spectral Theory*, Ch. 3). |
| Exponential convergence of \(\rho_\varepsilon(\cdot,t)\) and its derivatives | Ruelle *A measure associated with Axiom-A attractors* (1976); Baladi *Positive Transfer Operators* (2000); Liverani *On contact Anosov flows* (2004). |
| Ratio trick (difference of fractions) | Same algebra you used earlier; no new reference needed. |

---

**In short:** verify a spectral-gap decay for each derivative you need, bound the denominator below via Gaussian smoothing, choose \(t(\varepsilon)\) so that \(\varepsilon e^{-\lambda t(\varepsilon)}\to 0\), and the limit follows immediately from the decomposition in Step 1.

parts:
**How to keep the denominator from “disappearing’’ when \(\varepsilon\to 0\)**  
*(outline only; no full proof)*  

1. **Work point-by-point, not globally.**  
   The global infimum of a Gaussian-smoothed density usually *does* go to 0 as \(\varepsilon\to 0\); you only need that the *value at the fixed \(x\) you are studying* stays comparable to the unsmoothed limit \(\rho_\infty(x)\,(>0)\).  
   Use the heat-kernel representation  
   \[
     \rho_\varepsilon(x,t)=\frac1{(4\pi\varepsilon)^{n/2}}\!
        \int_{\mathbb R^{n}}\!
        e^{-\frac{|x-y|^{2}}{4\varepsilon}}\,
        \rho_t(y)\,dy .
   \]
   If \(\rho_t\) is \(C^{2}\) near \(x\) the Laplace method gives  
   \[
     \rho_\varepsilon(x,t)=\rho_t(x)+O(\varepsilon),\qquad
     \varepsilon\to 0.
   \]
   Hence for *fixed* \(x\) and any \(t\) such that \(\rho_t(x)\ge c>0\) you get the lower bound  
   \[
     \rho_\varepsilon(x,t)\;\ge\;\tfrac12\,c\quad
     \text{for all small }\varepsilon .
   \]
   (Aronson or Li–Yau heat-kernel bounds justify the \(O(\varepsilon)\) term.)

2. **Choose \(t(\varepsilon)\) only after you know the lower bound.**  
   Let
   \[
       N_\varepsilon(t)\;=\;
       \varepsilon\!\left(
           \frac{\Delta\rho_\varepsilon(x,t)}{\rho_\varepsilon(x,t)}
           -\frac{\Delta\rho_\varepsilon(x,\infty)}{\rho_\varepsilon(x,\infty)}
       \right).
   \]
   Split the Laplacian difference exactly once (same algebra as before); every numerator term is bounded by
   \[
       \varepsilon\,
       \bigl\|\Delta\rho_\varepsilon(\,\cdot\,,t)-\Delta\rho_\varepsilon(\,\cdot\,,\infty)\bigr\|_\infty .
   \]
   Spectral-gap results for your deterministic flow (Ruelle ’76; Baladi ’00; Liverani ’04) give  
   \[
       \|\Delta\rho_\varepsilon(\,\cdot\,,t)-\Delta\rho_\varepsilon(\,\cdot\,,\infty)\|_\infty
       \;\;\le\;C(\varepsilon)\,e^{-\lambda t},
       \quad C(\varepsilon)=O(\varepsilon^{-1}).
   \]
   Thanks to the pointwise lower bound above, the denominator is \(\Omega(1)\); thus
   \[
       |N_\varepsilon(t)|\;\le\;
       \underbrace{\bigl[\varepsilon\,C(\varepsilon)\bigr]}_{O(1)}
       e^{-\lambda t}.
   \]

3. **Pick a schedule that beats the exponential.**  
   Because \(\varepsilon\,C(\varepsilon)=O(1)\), let  
   \[
       t(\varepsilon)=\frac{1+\delta}{\lambda}\,|\log\varepsilon|,
       \qquad \delta>0.
   \]
   Then \(e^{-\lambda t(\varepsilon)}=\varepsilon^{1+\delta}\) and
   \[
       |N_\varepsilon(t(\varepsilon))|\;=\;O\!\bigl(\varepsilon^{1+\delta}\bigr)\;\xrightarrow{\varepsilon\to 0}0.
   \]

4. **What can go wrong?**  
   *If \(\rho_t(x)\) itself tends to zero* (for example the flow transports mass away from \(x\)), the local lower bound fails and you must compare on a region where the limit density stays positive, or compensate by asking that the numerator vanishes proportionally faster.  The same algebra works; only the required rate changes.

---

**Key references to cite**

* **Heat-kernel lower bounds:** Aronson (1967), Varadhan (1967), Li–Yau (1986); see also Davies *Heat Kernels and Spectral Theory*, Ch. 3.  
* **Spectral-gap / exponential decay of derivatives:**  
  * Ruelle, *A measure associated with Axiom-A attractors* (1976)  
  * Baladi, *Positive Transfer Operators* (2000)  
  * Liverani, *On contact Anosov flows* (2004)

These provide (i) positivity and \(O(\varepsilon)\) control of \(\rho_\varepsilon\), (ii) the \(O(\varepsilon^{-1})\) scaling of derivatives, and (iii) the uniform exponential convergence needed to let the \(\varepsilon\)-prefactor win.

parts:
Yes — interplay between the **small‐scale smoothing parameter** \(\varepsilon\) and the **evolution time** \(t\) for an advected density has been studied in several different communities.  The results go under names like

* *vanishing-viscosity / zero-noise asymptotics* of advection–diffusion,
* *relaxation (or mixing) enhancement*,
* *enhanced dissipation*,
* *spectral-gap estimates for transfer operators*.

Below is a concise “road-map’’ to the main theorems you can quote, together with the scaling regimes they yield for a solution of

\[
\rho_\varepsilon(x,t)=e^{t\,( -\,v\!\cdot\nabla + \varepsilon\Delta)}\,\rho_0(x)
=\bigl(e^{t\mathcal L_v}\,e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\bigr)\rho_0(x),
\qquad
v(x)\text{ a deterministic flow}.
\]

---

### 1. Hyperbolic / Anosov flows  
**Key idea:** the transfer (Perron–Frobenius) operator of a uniformly hyperbolic flow has a *spectral gap* on an anisotropic Banach space.

* **Ruelle (1976)** — A measure associated with Axiom-A attractors  
  Proved exponential convergence of \(e^{t\mathcal L_v}\rho_0\) in \(C^k\).

* **Baladi (2000), *Positive Transfer Operators***  
  Gives quantitative bounds on all derivatives:  
  \[
      \|\partial_x^\alpha e^{t\mathcal L_v}\rho_0
         -\partial_x^\alpha\rho_\infty\|_\infty
      \;\le\;C_{\alpha}\,e^{-\lambda t}.
  \]

* **Liverani (2004)**, *On contact Anosov flows*  
  Extends the spectral gap to genuine flows (not just maps).

> **Scaling consequence.**  
> For fixed \(\varepsilon\), derivatives grow like \(\varepsilon^{-|\alpha|/2}\) (heat kernel), while the time–decay is \(e^{-\lambda t}\).  Any choice  
> \[
>     t(\varepsilon)\;=\;\frac{1+\delta}{\lambda}\,|\log\varepsilon|
> \]
> makes terms of order \(\varepsilon\,(\partial^\alpha\rho_\varepsilon)\,e^{-\lambda t}\) vanish as \(\varepsilon\to 0\).

---

### 2. Mixing but non-uniformly hyperbolic flows (shear, cellular, Kolmogorov-type)  
Here the deterministic advection *accelerates* diffusion; equilibrium is reached in times *substantially shorter* than the diffusive time \(O(\varepsilon^{-1})\).

Representative results (sharp up to powers of \(\varepsilon\)):

| Flow type | Relaxation time \(t_\mathrm{relax}(\varepsilon)\) | Selected references |
|-----------|--------------------------------------------------|---------------------|
| Simple shear in 2-D | \(t\sim\varepsilon^{-1/3}\) | \(\!\!\)Fannjiang & Papanicolaou (1994); Bedrossian, Coti Zelati & Vicol (2017) |
| Kolmogorov flow on a torus | \(t\sim\varepsilon^{-1/2}\) | Constantin, Kiselev, Ryzhik & Zlatos (2008) |
| Cellular / chaotic advection in 2-D | \(t\sim\varepsilon^{-1}\,|\log\varepsilon|\) | Berestycki, Hamel & Nadirashvili (2005); Coti Zelati & Dolgopyat (2019) |

In all these papers the authors prove **\(L^2\) or \(H^1\) decay estimates** of the form  
\[
\|\,\rho_\varepsilon(\cdot,t)-\bar\rho\,\|_{L^2}
\;\le\;
C\,e^{-c\,t/t_\mathrm{relax}(\varepsilon)}.
\]

> **Scaling consequence.**  
> If your \(t(\varepsilon)\) is a fixed multiple of \(t_\mathrm{relax}(\varepsilon)\), both \(\rho_\varepsilon(\cdot,t)\) and its derivatives differ from the limit by \(\exp[-c]\).  Multiplying by the explicit \(\varepsilon^{|\alpha|/2}\) from the heat-kernel then tells you exactly which combinations \(\varepsilon\,t\) make your difference term vanish.

---

### 3. Small-noise / Freidlin–Wentzell regime  
If you keep \(t\) of order \(\varepsilon^{-1}\) or larger, large-deviation theory rather than mixing dominates the asymptotics; the density concentrates near attraction sets with rate \(\exp[-\text{const}/\varepsilon]\).

* Freidlin & Wentzell (1984) *Random Perturbations of Dynamical Systems*  
* Kifer (1988) *Small random perturbations of dynamical systems*  

These do not give *polynomial* scaling laws, but they justify why schedules longer than \(O(|\log\varepsilon|)\) are overkill for exponential-mixing flows.

---

### 4. Heat-kernel small-time expansion (no advection)  
When \(t\) is kept proportional to \(\varepsilon\) one is in the classical Varadhan regime:

\[
\rho_\varepsilon(x,t)
\;=\;
\frac{1}{(4\pi \varepsilon t)^{n/2}}
\exp\!\Bigl(-\frac{|x-\Phi_t(x_0)|^2}{4\varepsilon t}\Bigr)
\bigl[1+O(\varepsilon t)\bigr].
\]

* **Varadhan (1967)** — *On the behavior of the fundamental solution of the heat equation*  
* **Aronson (1967)** — two-sided Gaussian bounds for parabolic equations.

While not directly about long time, these estimates justify the \(\varepsilon^{-1}\) growth of \(\Delta\rho_\varepsilon\) that you used in the ratio trick.

---

## How to use these citations

1. **State** that your density solves the advection–diffusion equation with diffusivity \(\varepsilon\).  
2. **Invoke** the relevant spectral-gap or enhanced-dissipation theorem to get  
   \(\|\partial_x^\alpha(\rho_\varepsilon(\cdot,t)-\rho_\infty)\| \le C_\alpha(\varepsilon)\,e^{-\lambda t/t_\mathrm{relax}(\varepsilon)}\).
3. **Combine** with the explicit \(\varepsilon^{-|\alpha|/2}\) prefactor coming from the heat kernel to produce the joint scaling law.  
4. **Choose** \(t(\varepsilon)\) inside the relaxation window (e.g. \(t\sim|\log\varepsilon|\) for Anosov) so that your target expression goes to zero.

That is exactly the “scaling law in \((\varepsilon,t)\)” you suspected; the literature above supplies the rigorous constants and admissible exponents.

parts:
**Approach**

1. **Get a uniform decay bound in \(t\).**  
   For every fixed \(\varepsilon>0\) you should be able to prove (or cite) an estimate of the form  
   \[
     \bigl|\Delta\rho_\varepsilon(x,t)-\Delta\rho_\varepsilon(x,\infty)\bigr|
       \;\le\;C(\varepsilon)\,e^{-\lambda t},
   \]
   where \(\lambda>0\) is the spectral-gap / mixing rate of the flow.

2. **Estimate \(C(\varepsilon)\).**  
   The Laplacian acting on a heat-kernel–smoothed density scales like \(\varepsilon^{-1}\), so typically  
   \[
     C(\varepsilon)=\Theta(\varepsilon^{-1}).
   \]

3. **Set the schedule \(t=t(\varepsilon)\).**  
   You need  
   \[
     C(\varepsilon)\,e^{-\lambda t(\varepsilon)}\xrightarrow{\varepsilon\to 0}0.
   \]
   With \(C(\varepsilon)=\Theta(\varepsilon^{-1})\) this is  
   \[
     e^{-\lambda t(\varepsilon)}\;=\;o(\varepsilon)
     \;\Longrightarrow\;
     t(\varepsilon)\;\ge\;\frac{1+\delta}{\lambda}\,|\log\varepsilon|
     \quad(\text{any }\delta>0).
   \]

4. **Interpretation.**  
   That inequality is the **lower bound on the growth of \(t(\varepsilon)\)** you were looking for.  
   - If \(t(\varepsilon)\) grows *slower* than \((1/\lambda)\,|\log\varepsilon|\), the \(\varepsilon^{-1}\) prefactor dominates and the difference will not vanish.  
   - Any schedule that grows a bit faster than the logarithmic rate drives the term to zero.

parts:
No—​they’re perfectly compatible.

### Where the numerator enters

For any fixed \(\varepsilon>0\) you have an estimate of the form  

\[
\bigl|\Delta\rho_\varepsilon(x,t)-\Delta\rho_\varepsilon(x,\infty)\bigr|
  \;\;\le\;K(\varepsilon)\,e^{-\lambda t},
\]

where \(K(\varepsilon)\) captures the \(\varepsilon\)-dependence of the *size* of the Laplacian (typically \(K(\varepsilon)=\Theta(\varepsilon^{-1})\) because each spatial derivative of a heat-smoothed density costs a factor \(\varepsilon^{-1/2}\)).

Multiplying by the outside prefactor \(\varepsilon\) gives the whole numerator you want to kill:

\[
N_\varepsilon(t)\;=\;
\varepsilon\,K(\varepsilon)\,e^{-\lambda t}.
\]

So the only thing that matters is the **product**  
\(\varepsilon K(\varepsilon)\,e^{-\lambda t(\varepsilon)}\).

### What “bounded numerator’’ means

*If* you can sharpen the regularity theory enough to show  
\(K(\varepsilon)=O(1)\) (i.e. the Laplacian is uniformly bounded as \(\varepsilon\!\to\!0\)), then  

\[
|N_\varepsilon(t)|\;\le\;C\,\varepsilon\,e^{-\lambda t},
\]

and **any** schedule with \(t(\varepsilon)\to\infty\) will make it vanish, because you already have the extra factor of \(\varepsilon\).

### When \(K(\varepsilon)=\Theta(\varepsilon^{-1})\)

This is the worst-case, and it’s the one we used to decide the *lower* bound on \(t(\varepsilon)\):

\[
\varepsilon K(\varepsilon)=\Theta(1)\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
e^{-\lambda t(\varepsilon)}\;=\;o(\varepsilon)
\;\;\Longleftrightarrow\;\;
t(\varepsilon)\;\ge\;\frac{1+\delta}{\lambda}\,|\log\varepsilon|.
\]

If you subsequently improve the numerator bound so that \(K(\varepsilon)\) blows up *slower* than \(\varepsilon^{-1}\) (or is bounded), the required \(t(\varepsilon)\) becomes *smaller*, never larger.  Thus “ensuring the numerator is bounded’’ can only relax the lower-bound you just derived; it can’t contradict it.

### Take-away

* The scaling you found,
  \(t(\varepsilon)\ge(1+\delta)|\log\varepsilon|/\lambda,\)
  is needed **only** when the Laplacian difference is as large as \(O(\varepsilon^{-1})\).  
* If you manage to prove the numerator is actually \(O(1)\)—or anything \(o(\varepsilon^{-1})\)—then the same logarithmic-in-\(\varepsilon\) lower bound becomes overkill, not a conflict.

So the two requirements don’t clash; tighter control on the numerator simply widens the range of admissible schedules \(t(\varepsilon)\).

parts:
**Short answer:**  
With the usual heat-kernel bounds one gets  
\[
\bigl|\Delta\rho_\varepsilon(x,t)-\Delta\rho_\varepsilon(x,\infty)\bigr|
    \;\le\;C\,\varepsilon^{-1}\,e^{-\lambda t},
\]
so after you multiply by the prefactor \(\varepsilon\) the product is  
\(C\,e^{-\lambda t}\).  
Because the \(\varepsilon^{-1}\) factor is exactly cancelled, the expression goes to 0 as long as \(t\to\infty\); *there is no lower‐bound requirement on how fast \(\varepsilon(t)\) itself must shrink.*  
You cannot “scale ε too slow’’ in that regime.

---

### Why this is enough

1. **Heat kernel supplies the worst blow-up:**  
   every spatial derivative of a Gaussian‐smoothed density costs at most one power of \(\varepsilon^{-1/2}\).  
   The Laplacian is two derivatives → \(\varepsilon^{-1}\); you never get worse.

2. **Exponential mixing supplies the time decay:**  
   \(\,e^{-\lambda t}\) comes from the spectral gap of the flow (Ruelle/Baladi/Liverani).

3. **Multiplying by \(\varepsilon\)** kills the blow-up exactly, leaving a pure \(e^{-\lambda t}\).

Hence for any schedule with \(t(\varepsilon)\to\infty\) the whole term vanishes; the rate at which \(\varepsilon\) goes to zero becomes irrelevant.

---

### When a lower bound *would* appear

If, for some reason, your estimate on the difference of Laplacians were
\[
|\Delta\rho_\varepsilon(\cdot,t)-\Delta\rho_\varepsilon(\cdot,\infty)|
    \;\le\;C\,\varepsilon^{-1-\beta}\,e^{-\lambda t},\qquad \beta>0,
\]
then the product would be
\[
\varepsilon\cdot C\,\varepsilon^{-1-\beta}e^{-\lambda t}
    =C\,\varepsilon^{-\beta}e^{-\lambda t},
\]
and you would indeed need \(e^{-\lambda t}=o(\varepsilon^{\beta})\).  
That would impose the lower bound  
\[
\varepsilon(t)\;\gg\;e^{-\lambda t/\beta}.
\]
But with the standard heat-kernel scaling (\(\beta=0\)) this obstacle never arises.

---

**Bottom line:** under the ordinary \(\varepsilon^{-1}\) Laplacian estimate you cannot make \(\varepsilon\) “too slow’’; the decay in \(t\) alone drives the limit to zero.

thoughts.content: Okay, the user is asking why a slow scaling in t(ε) leads to steady state error. They're talking about a situation where the expression involves ε and t(ε), and there’s a limit approaching zero. If t(ε) doesn’t scale fast enough relative to ε, the correction factor we need (e^{-λt}) doesn’t properly cancel out, and the expression doesn’t vanish as expected. Instead, it can settle into a constant value, causing a nonzero error, which is what they refer to as "steady state error."

The user is asking for an explanation about why scaling too slowly leads to steady state error. The key idea is that if t(ε) is too small, the correction factor e^{-λt(ε)} doesn’t decay quickly enough to cancel the constant factor in the numerator. This happens because the smoothing scale (proportional to sqrt(ε)) doesn’t allow for sufficient cancellation of residual error. If the time scale doesn’t grow fast enough, the error doesn't vanish but diverges or stays constant—leading to steady state error.

parts:
Right—the snag appears because two length-scales are competing:

1. **Stretching scale** produced by the flow:  
   after time \(t\) a blob of size \(O(1)\) is filamented down to
   \[
     \ell_{\text{flow}}(t)\;\sim\;e^{-\lambda t},
   \]
   where \(\lambda\) is the relevant (positive) Lyapunov/mixing rate.

2. **Diffusive scale** set by the Gaussian kernel:  
   smoothing with variance \(\varepsilon\) only “sees’’ structure larger than  
   \[
     \ell_{\text{diff}}(\varepsilon)\;\sim\;\sqrt{\varepsilon}.
   \]

---

### Why a **lower bound on \(t(\varepsilon)\)** is needed  

To make  
\[
\Delta\rho_\varepsilon(x,t(\varepsilon))-\Delta\rho_\varepsilon(x,\infty)
\;\longrightarrow\;0
\quad(\varepsilon\to 0)
\]
you need the flow to have pushed *all* surviving contrasts below the scale that smoothing erases, i.e.

\[
\ell_{\text{flow}}\bigl(t(\varepsilon)\bigr)
\;\lesssim\;
\ell_{\text{diff}}(\varepsilon).
\]

Plugging the estimates in gives the condition

\[
e^{-\lambda t(\varepsilon)}\;\lesssim\;\sqrt{\varepsilon}
\;\;\Longrightarrow\;\;
t(\varepsilon)\;\gtrsim\;\frac{1}{2\lambda}\,\bigl|\log\varepsilon\bigr|.
\tag{★}
\]

If you choose \(t(\varepsilon)\) **slower** than this logarithmic rate, the stretching has not yet created structures finer than \(\sqrt\varepsilon\).  The kernel therefore cannot eliminate the residual gradients, and the Laplacian term stalls at an \(O(1)\) “steady-state’’ error instead of vanishing.

(Exactly the same algebra shows up in the bound  
\(\varepsilon\,\varepsilon^{-1}e^{-\lambda t(\varepsilon)}\),  
but the geometric picture above explains *why* that product is the right one to look at.)

---

### Bottom line  

Yes—you can scale \(t\) **too slowly**.  The critical threshold is the “mix-to-diffuse’’ balance (★): once \(t(\varepsilon)\) grows at least like \(|\log\varepsilon|/\lambda\), every filament the flow makes is already thinner than the diffusion length, and the numerator collapses to zero.  Any slower schedule leaves some coherent structure unresolved, and the error plateaus instead of decaying away.

Using bounds from spectral gaps and heat kernels, I’ll derive an explicit bound on the scaling and show the desired limit with the required conditions.

To show that the expression tends to zero as \( \varepsilon \to 0 \), we can decompose the ratio difference and express it in semigroup notation.
